div.p: PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 837): idānīṃ vāhyalakṣāṇi siddhidāni śṛṇu priye | dhāraṇākhyā tu caitāni jñātavyāni viśeṣataḥ |SSP 2.28 (Ed. p. 39): atha bahirlakṣyaṃ kathyate| nāsāgrāt bahiraṅgulacatuṣṭaye nīlajyotiḥsaṃkāśaṃ lakṣayet |idānīṃ bāhyalakṣyaṃlakṣyaṃṣāhyalakṣabāhyalakṣa°lakṣaṃ°lakṣaṇa°lakṣyaḥlakṣaṇaṃ kathyate/ nāsāgrād ārabhyāṅgulacatuṣṭaya catuṣṭayaṃpramāṇaṃ nīlākāraṃnilākaraṃnirākāraṃ tejatejaḥjaḥpūrṇam āpūrṇakāmkāśaākāśaṃlakṣyaṃlakṣaṃlakṣaṇaṃ kartavyaṃ/ PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 837): līlayā bhāvayel līnaṃ jyotiḥpūrṇaṃ mahāparam | atha vā tatra deveśi dhūmrākāraṃ ṣaḍaṅgulam |SSP 2.28 (Ed. p. 39): atha vā nāsāgrād ṣaḍaṅgulam adhovāyutattvaṃ dhūmravarṇaṃ lakṣayet |atha vā nāsāgrād ārabhyanāsāgrād ābhyanāsāgrārabhya ṣaḍaṃgulapramāṇaṃṣaḍaṃgulaṃ pramāṇaṃdvadaśaṃgulapramāṇaṃ pavanatattvaṃ°tatvaṃ\illeg dhūmrākāraṃ\illeg lakṣyaṃlakṣaṃlakṣaṇaṃ karttavyaṃ/Sentence is om.in L.PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 837): atha vāṣṭāṅgulaṃ raktaṃ nāsikopari lakṣayet |SSP 2.28 (Ed. p. 39): atha vā aṣṭāṅgula āraktaṃ tejastattvaṃ lakṣayet |atha vāom. nāsāgrād ārabhyāṣṭaṃgulapramāṇam aārabhyā ṣaḍaṃgulapramāṇāmārabhya ṣaḍaṃgulapramāṇāmārabhyaṃ ṣṭāṃgulapramāṇamārabhyaṃ ṣṭagulapramāṇaṃtiraktaṃatirattaṃitiriktaṃmatiraktaṃ tejoteja° lakṣyaṃlakṣaṃlakṣaṇaṃ karttavyaṃ/Sentence om.in \beta , except for U2.The instruction for a ten finger wide distance is absent in the surviving testimonia of the Yogasvarodaya. However, it can be found in another source text of the Yogatattvabindu, the ssplonavla 2.28 (Ed. p. 39).SSP 2.28 (Ed. p. 39): atha vā daśāṅgule kallolavad āpas tattvaṃ lakṣayet |atha vā nāsāgrād ārabhya daśāṅgulapramāṇaṃ śuklaṃ cañcalamcaṃdrākāram udakaṃ lakṣyaṃlakṣyalakṣaṇaṃlakṣaṃ kartavyaṃ/Sentence om.in \beta , except for U2.[5] PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 837): dvādaśāṅgulamānaṃ vā pṛthvītattvan tu pītabham | lakṣayed atha vā tatra koṭisūryasamaprabham | tejaḥ puñjaṃ mahākāśaṃ tattad dhyānāc chivo bhavet | ākāśamadhye ākāśoparito dṛṣṭis usthiram | kṛtvā dhyānād vinā sūryaṃ caṇḍasūryan tu paśyati | atha vā lakṣam etat tu karttur vahiḥ śivopari |SSP 2.28 (Ed. p. 39): atha vā nāsāgrād dvādaśāṅgule pītavarṇaṃ pārthivatattvaṃ lakṣayet |atha vā nāsāgrād ārabhya dvādaśāṃgulapramāṇaṃtattvaṃ dvādaśāṃgulapramāṇaṃdvādaśā aṃgulapramāṇaṃ pītavarṇaṃ pṛthvītattvaṃ lakṣyaṃlakṣaṇaṃlakṣaṃ kartavyaṃ/ SSP 2.28 (Ed. p. 40): atha vā ākāśamukhaṃ dṛṣṭvā lakṣayat kiraṇākulitaṃ paśyati |atha vā nāsāgrād ārabhya koṭisūryasamaprabhaṃ°prabhāṃ tejaḥpūrṇam ātejaḥ | pūrṇaṃpūrṇaṃpūrṇakāśatattvaṃ lakṣyaṃlakṣaṃlakṣaṇaṃ karttavyaṃ/

\ldots see in the source, PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 837): ``Having gained discrimination of the self, one calms the restless mind. Having seen darkness of ignorance caused by sense objects, one knows the supreme soul and becomes a soul beyond illusion, free from attachment to worldly pleasures, and goes through birth and death in truth, again and again. Abandoning aversion etc. [and] riches, which increase suffering like poison, one is liberated by Jñānayoga, which is as powerful as millions of suns.'' This oberservation perfectly suits the initial definition of Rājayoga (cf. 1.3, p.) in which it is defined as a practice that works even if the practitioner is leading an exuberant wealthty lifestyle. Now the external fixation is taught. Beginning at a four finger wide distance from the tip of the nose, the space element, appearing blue, being full of light, shall be made the target [of fixation]. Or, beginning at a six finger wide distance from the tip of the nose, the wind element, appearing greyish, shall be made the target [of fixation]. Or, beginning at an eight finger wide distance from the tip of the nose, the very red fire element shall be made the target [of fixation]. Or, beginning at a ten finger wide distance from the tip of the nose, the white fickle water element, shall be made the target [of fixation].[5] Or, beginning at a twelve finger wide distance from the tip of the nose, the yellow coloured earth element shall be made the target [of fixation]. Or, beginning at the tip of the noseGiven the explicit instructions of the respective distance of the exercise in the previous sentences, it is surprising that this instruction is lacking the mention of the distance. the space element full of fire shining like ten million suns shall be made the target [of fixation].The first five external targets, associated with the five elements can be also identified within sarvangayoga 3.29 33 (Ed. pp. 104 105). bāhya lakṣa aur puni jāṃnahūṃ | paṃca tatva kī lakṣa su ṭhānahuṃ | agra nāsikā aṃgula cārī | nīla varṇa nabha deṣi bicārī || 29 || nāsā agra aṃgul chah deṣaiṃ | dhūmrahi varṇ vāyu tat peśai | aṃgul aṣṭa nāsikā āgai | rakta varṇ su vahni tat jāgai || 30 || nāsā agra aṃgul daś tāṃī | śvet varṇ jal deṣi tahāṃī | nāsā agra su aṃgul bārā | pīta varṇ bhū deṣi apārā || 31 || bāhya lakṣa aur bahuterī | so jānaṃ jo pāvai serī | sataguru kṛpā karai jau kabahī | dei batāi chinak maiṃ sabahī || 32 || (29) Contemplate the external target repeatedly; focusing on the five elements. \ldots

SSP 2.28 (Ed. p. 40): evaṃ nirmalīkaraṇam| atha vordhvadṛṣṭayāntarālaṃ lakṣayet | jyotir mukhāni paśyati | atha vā yatra tatrākāśaṃ lakṣayet | ākāśasadṛśaṃ cittaṃ muktipradaṃ bhavati |ākāśamadhyeom. ākāśopariākāśoparī vāom. dṛṣṭiṃdṛṣṭiom. kṛtvākṛtvā ākāśamadhyeākāśamadhye dhyānakāraṇāt sūryaṃsūrya vinā sūryasaṃbaṃdhīnīṃsūryasaṃbaṃdhinī sahasrakiraṇāvalīṃsahasrakiraṇāvaliṃsahasrakiraṇāvalisahasrakiraṇapaṅktīḥsahasrāṇy api kīraṇāṇisahasrāṇapi kiraṇāṇi paśyatipaśyatīpaśyatepatipaśyaṃti/ PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 837): ūrddhvaṃ saptadaśāṅgulyaṃ pramāṇaṃ tejasā prabham |atha vāatha kāom. śiropary ūśiropariśivopariśiroparirom.rddhvaṃūrdhva°urdhvamūrddhaṃvṛddhaṃom. saptadaśāṃgulapramāṇaṃsaptadaśāṃgulaṃ parāṇaṃsaptadaśāṃgulapramāṇa°om. tejaḥpuṃjalakṣyaṃtejaḥpūṃjaṃ lakṣaṇaṃtejaḥpūṃjaṃ lakṣaṃtejā puṃjalakṣaṃtejā puṃjalakṣyaṃtejaḥpuṃjalakṣaṇaṃtejaḥpuṃjakaṃ lakṣyaṃtejaḥpuṃjaṃ lakṣyaṃ karttavyaṃ/ PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 837): ūrddhvaṃ saptadaśāṅgulyaṃ pramāṇaṃ tejasā prabham | athavā pṛthivītattvaṃ taptakāñcanasannibham | dṛṣṭiragre tu karttavyaṃ lakṣam etad yat ātmanām | uktānāṃ yasya kasyaiva ekaśaḥ karaṇaṃ priye | balīpalitahīnaḥ syādauṣadhena vinā tathā |SSP 2.28 (Ed. p. 40): atha vā dṛṣṭyā taptakāñcanasannibhāṃ bhūmiṃ lakṣayet | dṛṣṭiḥ sthirā bhavati | ity anekavidhaṃ bahirlakṣyam |atha vā dṛṣṭer agreagne taptasvarṇavarṇākāraṃtaptasvarṇavarṇakāraṃtatparaṃ svarṇākāraṃtaptasuvarṇavarṇataptavarṇākāraṃ pṛthvītattvaṃpṛthivītatvaṃpṛthītatvaṃpṛthvīṃ tatvaṃ lakṣyaṃlakṣaṃlakṣaṇaṃ karttavyaṃom./[10] uktānāṃ lakṣyāṇāṃlakṣyaṇāṃlakṣyaṇaṃlakṣaṇānāṃlakṣaṇaṃlakṣāṇā°lakṣāṃ madhye yasya kasyāpy ekasyāpikasyāp°lasyāpykasyakasyaelasya lakṣyalakṣa°lakṣasyalakṣaṇasyalakṣyasyakaraṇātkaraṇā valitapalitā dūrevalitaṃ palitādi dūrevalitapalitādidūre bhavantibhavatībhavati/ PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 837): sarvarogāṇi naśyanti mitravac ca vaśī ripuḥ | jīved varṣasahasran tu sarvalokeṣu pūjitaḥ | jihvāgre prabhaved vidyā vinā śāstrāvalokanāt |aṅgarogāaṃgarogāḥaṃgirogādi vinauṣadhaṃ dūredūrīdūro bhavantibhavatibhavatī/ samagrāḥsamagrāsamagra° svapnesvapinsvacan 'pipyaevaevan mitratāmmitranmityaṃnityaṃmitevaṃ ayāṃtiayāṃtīāyāṃtināyāṃtināyātinaiyati/ sahasravarṣaparyaṃtam āsahasravarṣamyuṣaṃāyuṣyaṃāyur vardhate/ apaṭhitaṃapathitaṃ śāstraṃ jihvāgreṇoccarate°rati°ratī/[15] etādṛśaṃetādṛśyaṃ bahutaraṃ phalaṃphalaṃ bahutaraṃ// Witness P includes a dittography of the previous lines after 24.16 and reads: etādṛśaṃ mitratāmāyāṃti sahasravarṣam āyur varddhate apaṭhitaṃ śāstraṃ jihvāgreṇoccarati etādṛśaṃ phalaṃ bahutaraṃ bhavati |.

\ldots Four fingers above the tip of the nose; contemplate the blue colored space element. (30) Six fingers from the tip of the nose visualize the smoke coloured air element. Eight fingers in front of the nose visualize the red coloured fire element. (31) Ten fingers from the tip of the nose visualize the white colored water element. Twelve fingers in front of the nose visualize the earth element with a yellow color. (32) There are many external target, but only a few can attain the ultimate goal. If the true guru shows mercy at any time, they reveal the secret within. After having fixed the gaze on the space element or above the space element, due to the execution of meditation [on either target], he sees the sun without the group of thousand rays related to the sun. Or, the mass of light situated seventeen finger wide distance above the head shall be made the fixation object. Or, at the uppermost part of the [previously mentioned] focal point, the earth element appearing in the colour of molten gold shall be made the target [of fixation].[10] From the execution of [the yoga of] targets onto any of the discussed targets, wrinkles, grey hair, etc., are removed. Diseases of the limbs are removed without medical herbs. All enemies become friends while sleeping. The lifespan increases up to 1000 years. The non recited scripture is uttered by the tip of the tongue.[15] Such [practice] yields numerous fruits.

idānīm aidānīṃntaralakṣyaṃanyataraṃ lakṣyaṃaṃtaraṃ lakṣyaṃantaralakṣaṃantaralakṣyakaṃaṇtaralakṣyaṇaṃataraṃ lakṣyaṃ kathyatekartavyaṃ/ PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 838): mūlakandotthatalato brahmanāḍīsamudbhavā | śvetavarṇā brahmarandhraparyantam eva tiṣṭhati | eṣā tu brahmarandhrākhyā tanmadhye varttate parā |SSP 2.26 (Ed. pp. 37 38): tatra tāvad antarlakṣyaṃ kathyate | mūlakandād daṇḍalagnāṃ brahmanāḍīṃ śvetavarṇāṃ brahmarandhraparyantaṃ gatāṃ saṃsmaret | tanmadhye kamalatantunibhāṃ vidyutkoṭiprabhām ūrdhvagāminīṃ tāṃ mūrtiṃ manasā lakṣayet | sarvasiddhipradā bhavati|mūlakandasthānemūlakaṃ sthāne brahmadaṇḍād utpannābrahmadaṇḍotpannā nāḍībrahmadaṃḍa ityannābrahmadaṇḍad ūtpannābrahmadaṇād ūtpannaḥ śvetavarṇā brahmarandhraparyaṃtaṃbrahmadaṇḍaparyantam ekā brahmanāḍīekā nāḍīekanāḍī vartate/ PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 838): padmatantusamākārā koṭisūryataḍitprabhā | calaty ūrddhaṃ mahāmūrttir asya dhyānād bhavec chivaḥ | aṇimādy aṣṭasiddhis tu samagreṇa prasīdati |Sentence om.in N2.brahmanāḍīmadhye kamalatantusamānākārākamalataṃ samānākārā koṭisūryavidyutsamaprabhā°bhāprabhā ūrdhvaṃ°rdhvaṃurdhvaṃ calati/ etādṛśy ekāetādṛśī ekāom. mūrtir vaom.rtateom./ tasyātasyāḥtanom. mūrter dhyāmūrteom.naom.kāraṇād a°karaṇāt°karaṇāc°om.ṣṭamahāsiddhayoaṇimādyaṣṭasiddhiḥaṇimādīsiddhiḥ 'ṇimādyāḥ'ṇimādayas tasyaaṇimādyāḥom. Witnesses P, B and L add a incomplete list of eight supernatural powers right after 25.4: aṇimāmahimālaghimāgarimādure vā yadi vā dure śrutvā parakāyāpraveśitā | Since the list is incomplete and corrupt and stemmatically most probable a later addition, it is not included within the edition's text.Sentences om.in N2.puruṣasya samīpesāmīpesamīpemsamīpamsamīm āgatyaāgamya tiṣṭhantitiṣṭhati/[5]

[25.1 9Antaralakṣya] Now the inner target is explained. Starting from the location of the root bulb (mūlakanda)There exist diverging concepts about the location of the kanda in yogic literature predating Rāmacandra. In the yajnavalkya 4.16 27 (Ed. p. 33), it is located in the centre of the belly, nine finger widths below the waist: kandasthānāṃ manuṣyāṇāṃ dehamadhyān navāṅgulam | caturaṅgulam utsedham āyāmaś ca tathāvidhaḥ ||16|| aṇḍākṛtivad ākāraṃ bhūṣitaṃ tattvagādhibhiḥ | catuṣpadāṃ tiraścāṃ ca dvijānāṃ tundamadhyame ||17|| ``The location of the bulb (kanda) of humans is nine finger widths from the waist. [It is] four finger widths in height and has the same [measure in] length. It appears like an egg, and [it is] ornamented with the five elements of creation and sustenance. In quadrupeds, birds and other beings, it is in the centre of the belly.'' \indent In the hathapradipika2024 3.64cd (gulphadeśasamīpe ca kandaṃ tatra prapīḍayet), the kanda is said to be located near the region of the ankles. The Gorakṣaśataka, the source for this verse in the hathapradipika2024 mentions pressing the kanda with the feet, which could imply that the kanda is in the genital region (except one assumes the very challenging posture like kandapīḍāsana, cf. encyclopediaasana Ed. pp. 143 144). Sundaradeva, in yuktabhavadeva 7.224 and Bhavadevamiśra in hathacandrika (ms. no. 2244, f. 36r) argue that the kanda is near the navel. originating from the staff of BrahmaThe term brahmadaṇḍa in this context refers to the spinal column, which is usually identified with Mt. Meru in tantric texts, cf. stupa., being white, extending up to the aperture of Brahma [at the top of the head] exists the single Brahma channelThe term brahmanāḍī is used as a synonym for the suṣūmnā, cf., e.g. hathapradipika2024 2.67, mallinson2012sataka 47, yogakundalinyopanisad 37c 38b, yogacintamani (Ed. pp. 46, 112, 116, 140, 191), hatharatnavali 2.8, 2.25, 2.65, 2.69. Within the Brahma channel [exists something] resembling the shape of a stalk of a lotus flower shining like 10 million suns [which] goes upwards. [There] exists only one such manifestation. Due to the execution of meditation on this manifestationA predecessor of this type of meditation is found in bäumer2013 35 (madhyanāḍī madhyasaṃsthā bisasūtrābharūpayā | dhyātāntarvyomayā devyā tayā devaḥ prakāśate |) ``The central channel, which is situated within the centre of the body [is endowed] with a form resembling the stalk of a lotus. By meditation upon it's the empty inner space god becomes revealed by the goddess [of the middle].'', the eight supernatural powers of humans beginning with ``becoming as small as the smallest particle of matter'' (aṇima) etc.For an extensive discussion about the yogic supernatural powers (siddhis), see yogapowers2017 (2017). become established after entering [the manifestation's] imminence.[5]

PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 838): lalāṭopari vā dhyātvā candraṃ vā jyotir īśvaram | nāśayet kuṣṭharogādīn mahāyuṣmān śivaḥ paraḥ |SSP 2.27 (Ed. p. 38): atha vā lalāṭordhve kollāṭamaṇḍape sphuratkārākāraṃ lakṣayet|atha vā lalāṭopary ālalāṭoparikāśamadhye śuklasadṛśasya tejaso dhyānakāraṇāc chadhyānakāraṇātrīraśarīra°sambandhinaḥ°sambandhī kuṣṭhādayokuṣṭādayo rogārogāḥ naśyantinaśyaṃtī/ āyur vṛddhir bhavati/ PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 832): bhruvor madhye 'thavā dhyātvā arkantu teja īśvaram | sthiradṛṣṭau rājapūjyo jīvanmuktaḥ śivo yathā | ātmānam ātmarūpaṃ hi dhyātvā yo niṣkriyo bhavet | nirāśīryatatattvo 'yaṃ itaro na nṛpasthitiḥ |atha vāom. bhruvor mabṛvordhye 'tiraktaatirakta°tirikta°varṇasyātisthūlasyavarṇasyātī sthalasya'tisthūlasyaḥ tejaso dhyānakaraṇāt sadhyānaṃ karaṇātdhyānakāraṇādkālānāṃsakalānābahulānāṃ pārthivapuruṣāṇāṃparthivānāṃ tatpuruṣāṇāṃ ca vallabhobhavatibhavati | jagad vallabho pi bhavati/ taṃasya puruṣaṃ dṛṣṭvāpuruṣaṃ dṛṣṭāpuruṣaṃpuruṣa°puruṣasyāvalokanena sarveṣāṃpratisarveṣāṃ dṛṣṭisthirādṛṣṭiḥ sthirā bhavatibhavatī//[9]

Or, from the execution of meditation onto the bright light within the space above the forehead: diseases related to the body, beginning with leprosy, vanish.The ssplonavla 2.27 (Ed. p. 38) includes three techniques of antarlakṣya which are unparalleled in Rāmacandra's system: atha vā bhramaraguhāmadhye āraktabhramarākāraṃ lakṣayet | atha vā karṇadvayaṃ tarjanībhyāṃ nirodhayet tataḥ śiromadhye dhūṃ dhūṃ kāraṃ nādaṃ śṛṇoti | atha vā cakṣurmadhye nīlajyotirūpaṃ putalyākāraṃ lakṣayed | ``Or, one should target the form of a very red bee within the bhrahmaraguhā. Or, one should close both ears with the index fingers and listen to the dhūṃ dhūṃ sound in the head. Or, one should target the form of a doll appearing in blue light within the eyes.'' Lifeforce increases. Alternatively, because of executing meditation on the very subtle red light in the middle of the eyebrows, he becomes one who is beloved among all royal people. Having seen this person, everybody's gaze becomes fixed [onto the person].[9]Examining the current context, it is puzzling why Rāmacandra, as well as the unknown author of the Yogasvarodaya, introduce the ten main channels and ten vital winds immediately after antaralakṣya instead of madhyalakṣya. The only one verse dedicated to antarlakṣa in the sarvangayoga 3.33 might provide a possible hint to an answer: aṃtar lakṣa ju sunahuṃ prakāśā | brahma nāḍikā karahu abhyāsā | aṣṭa siddhi nava niddhi jahāṃlauṃ | ṭarahiṃ na kabahūṃ jivai jahāṃ lauṃ || 33 || "Listen about the light of the inner target. Practice locating the channels within the body. There, you will attain the eight siddhis and nine treasures and never again have to return to the mortal world." In Sundardās's discussion of Lakṣyayoga, the channels become the targets of its practice. According to Sundardās, \ldots

SSP 1.66 (Ed. p. 29): atha nāḍīnāṃ daśadvārāṇi | iḍā piṅgalā ca nāsādvārayor vahataḥ | gāndhārī hastijihvikā ca cakṣurdvārayor vahataḥ | pūṣā yaśasvinī ca karṇadvārayor vahataḥ | alambuṣā ānane vahati | kuhūr gudadvāre vahati | śaṅkhinī liṅgadvāre vahati | suṣumṇā madhyadeśe vahati | sā daṇḍamārgeṇa brahmarandhraparyantaṃ vahati | evaṃ daśanāḍyo daśadvāreṣu vahanti | anyāḥ sarvanāḍyo romakūpeṣu vahanti |PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. p. 838): idānīṃ śṛṇu nāḍīnāṃ bhedaṃ vakṣyāmi siddhidam | meruvāhye iḍānāmnī piṅgalayā samanvitā | suṣumnā bhānumārgeṇa brahmadvārāvadhi sthitā | sarasvatī sugandhā tu gāndhārī hastijihvakā | jñātavyā karṇayormadhye netrayoś ca tathāntimā | pūṣā cālambuṣā ceti mūlasthā kutracit tathā | liṅgadvārādiḍāmārge brahmasthānāvadhi priye | nāḍyantaṃ pratilomeṣu sahasrāṇāṃ dvisaptatiḥ |idānīṃidānī śarīramadhye nāḍīnāṃnāḍī°nāḍīnām aparo bhedāḥbhedaḥ kathyantekathyate/ daśamukhyanāḍyaḥdaśamukhyānāḍyaḥdaśamukhyenāḍyādaśamukhyānāḍayasdaśamukhyanādhyaḥ/ tanmadhye [26.1 12The 10 Channels] \ldots the practice bestows siddhis. Even though not directly introduced as a practice, the unknown author of the Yogasvarodaya also informs the reader about the siddhi bestowing nature of the channels without any practical instructions (idānīṃ śṛṇu nāḍīnāṃ bhedaṃ vakṣyāmi siddhidam). It seems that in the Yogasvarodaya, the ten channels could have been a part of the practice of Antaralakṣya, too. However, both texts, the Yogasvarodaya, as well as Yogatattvabindu, do not directly indicate a practical usage of the taxonomy of the channels. Rather they present them in textbook style merely to inform about their existance, in the same way, the ssplonavla 1.66 presents them, but their position in the context remains suspicious. Now, the divisions of channels within the body are explained.Networks of channels are standard in many systems of yoga. The earliest known mention refers to Upaniṣadic literature, such as the brhadaranyaka 2.1.19. For a detailed depiction of systems of channels in yogic literature, see rootsofyoga2017. There are ten primary channels.The notion of ten primary channels can already be found in early texts of Haṭhayoga, e.g., the vivekamartandaold (Central Library, Baroda Acc. No. 4110, 1534 Saṃvat) 17 teṣu nāḍisahasreṣu dvisaptatir udāhṛtāḥ | pradhānāḥ prāṇavāhinyo bhūyas tatra daśa smṛtāḥ || ``Of those thousand channels, seventy two have been spoken of, and among them, ten are considered most important. They are the main pathways of the vital breaths.'' Also cf. fausta1976 34. However, the enumeration of ten main channels in yogic literature also has predecessors, e.g., in Śaivasiddhānta, cf. sardha 10.4 5. Other systems, e.g., yajnavalkya 4.26 or vasisthasamhita 2.21, enumerate fourteen primary channels. Among them is a pair of channels. [Their] designation is Idā and Piṅgalā [and they] exist at the entrance of the nose. The Suṣumṇā flows by the path of the sun to the door of Brahma.The brahmadvāra is a synonym for the brahmarandhra, ``The aperture of Brahmā/Brahman''; the fontanelle, through which the vital principle of the yogi exists at death, cf. rootsofyoga2017[5] The Sarasvatī[ channel] exists at the center of the face. The two rivers, Gāndhārī and Hastjihvā, exist within the two ears. The two rivers, Pūṣā and Ālaṃbuṣā, are situated at the center of the two eyes. Śaṃkhinī stretches from the beginning of the opening of the gender through the Iḍā channel up to the BrahmasthānaThe brahmasthānais another synonym for brahmarandhra. In dhyanabind 65, the brahmasthāna is equated with the sahasrāracakra.. Kuhū stretches from the entrance of the rootThe entrance of the root (mūladvāra) in this passage refers to the anus, cf. ssplonavla 1.66 (kuhūr gudadvāre vahati) ``Kuhū conducts through the anus''. through the Piṅgalā channel up to the Brahmasthāna.[10] In such a way, the channels are situated at the ten openings. The other channels, measured as 72000, are situated with a subtle form at the roots of the hairs.

karoti yogasaṃjñakaḥ | apāno gudadeśasthaḥ karoty ākuñcanaṃ sa tu | stambhanañ ca tathāpānaḥ samāno nābhimaṇḍale | toṣakādipoṣakan tu nāḍīnāṃ rūcidāyakaḥ | dīptāgnimadhye 'pi tathā samānākhyā mahāparā | tālumadhye udānas tu aśnāti pibatīti ca | śarīraṃ sakalaṃ vyāpya vyānavāyuḥ pratiṣṭhitaḥ | śarīre cālanaṃ teṣu karoti sthāpayaty api |SSP 1.67 (Ed. pp. 23 24): atha daśavāyavaḥ | hṛdaye prāṇavāyur avāyuḥvāyuskmr annaṃratnaṃ gilatilīlatigalayatīgalayatiśilati/ pānīyaṃ pibatipībatipibatī/ vyānavāyuḥnāgavāyuḥnāgavāyu°nānāgavāyuḥ sakalesakala°sarva° śarīre varttate/ I have emendend nāgavāyu to vyānavāyu based on the description provided in PTqcr \cdot YSV, as the latter term corresponds to the given function. Some witnesses, namely E, P, B, L and U2 contain a nonsensical fragment, ``śokam āpnoti vikṛtaḥ'', after the description of the vāyu. This is likely a remnant of the original description of nāgavāyu that was lost during transmission.tasmād vāskmd vāyoḥvāyo śarīraṃśarīre calayaticālayaticālatīcālayatīcalayaticalati/[15] śokam āpnoti vikṛtaḥśokam āpnoti vikrutaḥśokam āpnoti || vivilaḥśokam āpnoti vikutaḥśopham āpnoti vikṛtaḥśokam āpnoti vikṛtaḥom.

Now ten vital winds are situated within the body. Their functions are taught. The Prāṇa vital wind is located in the middle of the heart and causes inhalation and exhalation. There is a desire for food and drink. At the center of the anus, the Apāna vital wind exists.[5] He does contraction and checking. At the center of the navel, the Samāna vital wind exists. He causes to absorb [substances from]The term śoṣayati literally means ``causes to dry up'' or ``causes to disappear''. In this context however, a better ideomatic translation would be ``causes to absorp'', since the Samāna vital wind absorbs the eaten substances in the body and distributes it everywhere, cf. yajnavalkya 4.55 57 (Ed. p. 40) and 4.69ab (Ed. p. 42). all the channels. In this way, the channels are caused to be nourished, appetite is caused to be generated, and the fire [of digestion] is caused to light up.[10]Within the throat the Udāna vitalwind is situated. This wind swallows food, [and] it drinks water. The Vyāna vital wind exists in the entire body. Through the vital wind, the body is caused to move.[15] \ldots In the PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. pp. 838 839) the order of the ten vital winds is as follows: Prāṇa, Apāna, Samāna, Udāna, Vyāna, Kūrma, Nāga, Kṛkāra, Devadatta, Dhanañjaya. In the SSP 1.67 (Ed. pp. 23 24): Prāṇa, Apāna, Samāna, Vyāna, Udāna, Nāga, Kūrma, Kṛkāra, Devadatta, Dhanañjaya. In both texts, which are the probable sources and templates for Rāmacandra the Vyāna vital wind appears to be within the group of the first five major viral winds. This group of five winds is undoubtedly common across yogic literature, cf. rootsofyoga2017. The emergence of Nāga instead of Vyāna in the witnesses indicates corruption of transmission. The description of the function of the vital wind in this passage makes it likely that the term Vyāna was dropped, replaced with Nāga and in turn the description of the function of Nāga was lost. The odd phrase ``śokam āpnoti vikṛtaḥ'' might be a remainder of this lost description of Nāga. PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. pp. 838 839) reads: ``udgāre nāga ākhyātaḥ ūrddhavāyuḥ pracālane'' and SSP 1.67 (Ed. pp. 23 24) ``nāgavāyuḥ sarvāṅgavyāpakaḥ mocakaś cālakaś ca''. Based on these readings of the possible templates the passage still remains puzzling.

PTqcr \cdot YSV (Ed. pp. 838 839): netramadhye kūrmanāmā nimeṣonmeṣakṛdayam | udgāre nāga ākhyātaḥ ūrddhavāyuḥ pracālane | kṛkaraḥ kṣutkaro jñeyo devadatto vijṛmbhaṇe | dhanañcayaḥ saccidākāro mṛtadehaṃ na muñcati | yady api sargakāṇḍe sarvametaduktaṃ tathāpi kāryakāraṇabhāvajñāpanāya punarnirdiṣṭamiti na punaruktam |SSP 1.67 (Ed. pp. 23 24): kūrmavāyuḥ cakṣuṣor unmeṣakārakaś ca| kṛkalaḥ udgārakaḥ kṣutkārakaś ca | devadatto mukhavijṛmbhakaḥ | dhanañjayo nādaghoṣakah ||1.67|| iti daśavāyvavalokanena piṇḍotpattiḥ naranārīrūpam |kūrmavāyur nekūrmavāyoḥkūrmo vāyutramadhye tiṣṭhatiom./ nimeṣonmeṣaṃunmeṣaṃ nimeṣaṃunmeṣaṃ nimeṣaṃ ca karotikarotī/ Sentences om.in U1.kṛkalavāyor ukṛkalavāyurkṛkalakartāvāyurpuṣkaravāyurdgāroudgāraṃudhāraṃuhāraṃūdgāroūdgāto bhavatikarotikarotī/ devadattavāyor jṛdevadattavāyoḥdevadattavāyombhajṛmbhaṇaṃjumbhājṛṃbhājṛṃbho°jaṃbhā utpadyatebhavatibhavaṃtībhavatī/ dhanaṃjayavāyoḥdhanaṃjayavāyo śabdaśabdāḥśabdaḥśabdo°sabta utpadyate//[20]

The Kūrma vital wind exists within the eyes. It causes [the] opening and closing [of the eyes]. From the Kṛkala, vital wind gagging arises. From the Devadatta, vital wind jawning arises. From the Dhanaṃjaya, vital wind speech arises.[20]
